Award.AwardTitle: HCC: Medium: New Technology Supports for Learning in Embodied Science Inquiry Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project centers on the design of technologies than can help teachers and students to effectively enact the kinds of complex, challenging instructional designs that characterize modern science pedagogy. While considerable effort has gone into the development of technologies to support learners who are seated at computers, this project will address the largely unexplored domain of embodied, whole-class science inquiry activities that are largely unmediated by traditional one-to-one technologies. The project focuses on "embedded phenomena" instructional units in which elementary school students conduct investigations of persistent, room-sized simulated phenomena over multi-week periods. Through a series of iterative design studies, the project will build and evaluate technology-based supports for teachers and students addressing three critical goals: (a) improving students' abilities to conduct accurate and reliable scientific investigations, (b) ensuring the regular and meaningful participation of all classroom students in collaborative investigations, and (c) helping students to effectively integrate, manipulate, and represent the results of their collective scientific work. The new technologies developed in the project will serve as foundational building blocks for a flexible, sustainable learning technology infrastructure supporting ambitious STEM instruction.

Broader impacts: The project will help students and teachers, particularly in the elementary and middle school grades, to overcome barriers to engaging in innovative but complex pedagogical forms that have the potential to transform science education. It will promote high-fidelity enactment of science practices, help to ensure that opportunities for participation are distributed throughout classes of students, and inform the design of new pedagogical approaches. The tangible products of the project-including new technologies, new instructional units, and evaluations of their effectiveness in supporting STEM learning-will be made broadly available to teachers, learning researchers, and technology developers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Much of contemporary science practice involves coordinated programs of collaborative work conducted by teams of researchers. Understanding how scientists work, and preparing learners to engage in that work, require experiences—the patient observation and manipulation of scientific phenomena over long time periods, the capture, preservation, and aggregation of research community data and knowledge, and the establishment of consensus and growth of community knowledge—that are difficult to provide in elementary school science classrooms.

This research has developed an instructional method and web-based coordinated technology supports that enable elementary school students and teachers to experience this kind of "patient science." Students are given access to room-size, dynamic simulations of scientific phenomena that require study by teams of students over curriculum units lasting 6-10 weeks. They are provided with software tools for recording observations of the phenomena, conducting experiments with the phenomena, and aggregating and analyzing their results. Knowledge building tools allow students to leverage the work of their fellow researchers, share their theories and the reasoning behind them, and build consensus around models of the phenomenon. This framework and its supporting technologies are the basis for four curriculum units (in astronomy, seismology, foraging, and ecosystem population dynamics) that were developed and refined during the project, and enacted in over two dozen school classrooms, serving more than 350 students over the course of the project.

In these units, activity in the classroom is distributed and dynamic. Students move around the room to access different parts of the phenomenon under study, cluster around large displays that provide real-time visualizations of their work, and meet in small groups at tables or sprawled on the floor. Under these conditions, teachers need help in understanding whether students are developing skills in the practice of science, participating in ways that allow them to develop those skills, and developing deeper understandings of both the phenomenon under study and the nature of scientific research.

This research addressed these challenges through the development of measurement and feedback tools. The project developed monitoring and reporting software that allowed teachers to compare students' reported observations of simulated phenomena with the "ground truth" provided by the underlying computational model, and provided profiles of individual learner interaction with the suite of digital learning resources. These tools are useful for identifying symptomatic behaviors, but require the teacher to serve as a monitor and mediator of performance.

To complement these tools, the project developed technologies that displayed real-time public representations of student activity such as reporting a reading from a simulated instrument. Of particular value were representations that aggregated "crowd-sourced" observations in a way that allowed students to identify their contributions and compare them against those of multiple peers. These representations became the focus of intense student interest, fostered refinements of practice, and helped the community to guide their collective work by highlighting controversial and underexplored characteristics of the phenomenon.

The research team investigated the potential for using discrete location radio-based tracking systems (RFID and Bluetooth LE) to track students' physical movement among action areas, but found that the sharp surfaces and density of bodies in classrooms made these technologies too unreliable for that purpose. These technologies proved valuable, however, as a mechanism for near-field recognition of tangibles with embedded tags. The project showed how a small number of such tangibles could be used to support whole class participatory simulations and to control the classroom simulation.

An additional outcome from the research was the development and refinement of versatile and reliable software infrastructures for constructing and running the suites of software tools needed to support these complex curriculum units. These resources have been made publicly available in Github repositories https://github.com/nutella-framework and https://github.com/educoder, and are serving as the software infrastructures for new collaborative projects.

Work on this project served as the basis for three Ph.D. dissertations (one in computer science, and two in the learning sciences) and two M.S. degrees (in computer science).
